<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
FOOD & BEV
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/05/20/oatly-ipos-12b-valuation?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Investors Feeling Like a Kid in an Oat Milk Store
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/05/20/oatly-ipos-12b-valuation" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="An illustration of Oatly's light blue oat milk carton. Some loose oats are scattered around its base, and a few oat stalks are sticking out of the hole at the top like it's a vase. " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC81MTU2L29hdGx5LmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The humble oat has gotten a glow up from its days starring in grandma's porridge. Yesterday, shares in Oatly, the world's biggest oat milk maker, <a href="https://apnews.com/article/europe-lifestyle-health-business-f5bf285bf70e1bf73d050656d110aa7e?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">soared</a> 19% in its IPO, valuing the company at a trenta-sized $12 billion. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">$12 billion for...oat milk?</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">If CEO Toni Petersson <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_HQU0MB0D5A" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">singing</a>, "wow, no cow" at the Super Bowl was your Oatly introduction...we regret to inform you that you were behind on this one.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Oatly's story <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2021/05/20/oatly-ipo-how-the-swedish-oat-milk-became-popular-in-us.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">starts</a> in 1994, when Swedish brothers Rickard and Bjorn Oeste began developing a milk alternative for the estimated two-thirds of people with lactose intolerance. But the company didn't become a household name until Petersson took over as CEO in 2014, refreshing Oatly's visual identity and reframing its marketing around oat milk's health and environmental benefits. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Petersson focused on the US market and built buzz by infiltrating corporate watering holes, i.e. NYC coffee shops. Oatly sent its product to specialty baristas, who introduced consumers to the new milk in a perfectly frothed form you'd never be able to replicate at home. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Since then, Oatly's been keeping some A-list company. It <a href="https://www.reuters.com/article/us-oatly-funding-idUSKCN24F1MG?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">raised</a> money last year at a $2 billion valuation from names including Blackstone, Oprah, Natalie Portman, and Howard Schultz (whose former company, Starbucks, recently began using Oatly nationwide). Oatly's expanded to new products, including yogurt and ice cream, and now sells in 60k stores and 32k coffee shops worldwide.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">The alternative milk market is steaming up</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">And plenty of brands are scrambling for a spot on the menu. In the oat department alone, Oatly's got competition from Califia Farms, Chobani, Planet Oat, Pacific, and Danone's legacy alternative milk brands, Alpro and Silk.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">But oat milk is still second fiddle to almond milk. And a gander through your local grocery store’s dairy aisle will show you that companies are juicing every nut, grain, seed, and bean that can (even loosely) mimic the "real" thing.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line:</strong> Oatly and other alternative milk brands seized on consumer demand for more environmentally friendly and healthy products. Their bet is paying off. </p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
INVESTING
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/05/20/robinhood-now-offering-ipo-shares?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Robinhood Puts the Public in IPO
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/05/20/robinhood-now-offering-ipo-shares" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Robinhood illustration " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yMTI3L3JvYmluaG9vZF9pbGx1c3RyYXRpb24uanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em></em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Robinhood wants to clear up any hard feelings left over from January and yesterday <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2021/05/20/robinhood-will-give-retail-investors-access-to-ipo-shares-a-longstanding-wall-street-dominion.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">announced</a> that it’s rolling out a feature that allows users to access exclusive “IPO shares.” It touts this new service as another step in its mission to increase regular folks’ access to the stock market. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">How IPO shares work: </strong>Big Wall Street banks and high-net-worth individuals are often able to buy shares of a company that’s going public <em>before </em>they hit an exchange like Robinhood. And once those stocks do hit an exchange, regular investors can miss out on early gains. Companies popped an average of 36% on their first day of trading in 2020, per Dealogic.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">The guinea pig: </strong></span><span>Figs, a maker of medical scrubs, became the </span><span><a href="https://www.reuters.com/technology/robinhood-allow-users-buy-into-ipos-2021-05-20/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">first company</a></span><span> to offer IPO shares on Robinhood when it went public yesterday, reserving 1% of its 22.5 million shares for Robinhood users.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out:</strong> SoFi, the fintech company that keeps asking if it can refinance your student loans, announced it would offer IPO shares in March. The main difference between SoFi’s and Robinhood’s offerings is that SoFi will be underwriting IPOs, while Robinhood is simply partnering with investment banks.</p>

<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
ARCHITECTURE
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/05/20/billionaire-barry-dillers-260-million-island-opens-weekend?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Little Island for the Big Apple
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>

<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/05/20/billionaire-barry-dillers-260-million-island-opens-weekend" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Little Island from the Esplanade in New York" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC81MTU3L2xpdHRsZV9pc2xhbmQuanBlZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Michael Grimm</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">If you can't find us this weekend, check the 2.4-acre floating <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/05/20/arts/little-island-barry-diller.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Little Island</a>, which opens today on New York City's west side. Check the 687-seat amphitheater. Check everything else: </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>A packed schedule of 500 events from June 15 through September</span></li>
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>$6 million worth of poles that surround the island to prevent people from falling into the Hudson River below</span></li>
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Ticketed entry</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The $260 million park was mostly funded by Barry Diller, a billionaire media mogul who has been working on the project since 2013.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Diller is protective of Little Island, </span><span><a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/little-island-park-barry-diller-diane-von-furstenberg-11621508053?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">promising</a></span><span> that it will never host a wedding: "The island is not for rent!" his wife, designer Diane von Furstenburg, told the WSJ.</span>
</li>
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Diller also promised to cover programming and upkeep for at least the next 10 years, so his family foundation could end up spending an estimated $380 million in total.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture:</strong> The Little Island is one of several projects transforming the far west side of Manhattan. The relocation of the Whitney Museum in 2015, the High Line park, and an <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/10/13/nyregion/big-tech-nyc-office-space.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">expansion</a> of Big Tech companies' offices have dramatically changed the area in the last decade.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">P.S. Doesn't it also kinda look like the <a href="https://www.crackerbarrel.com/shop/toys-games/games/travel-games/peg-game?sku=606154" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Cracker Barrel peg game</a>?</p>

<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">For the millions of people suffering from anxiety, depression, or mental distress, chances are the drugs their doctor is prescribing will not do the trick.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">See, many of the current treatments for mental health disorders are ineffective, as 50%–66% of patients on antidepressants never make a full recovery. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Enter <a href="https://invest.ei.ventures/mb?utm_source=morningbrew&utm_medium=0521" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Ei.Ventures and the potential healing power of psychedelic therapies</a>.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Psilocybin mushrooms (also known as “magic mushrooms”) and other psychedelic compounds like LSD and MDMA have the potential to go mainstream, creating what could become a $100 billion market. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">When you <a href="https://invest.ei.ventures/mb?utm_source=morningbrew&utm_medium=0521" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">invest in Ei.Ventures</a>, you’re funding treatments that have the potential to<em> actually </em>work. In fact, early research studies have shown that psychedelic therapies may help in a variety of mental health indications.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><a href="https://invest.ei.ventures/mb?utm_source=morningbrew&utm_medium=0521" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Invest In Ei.Ventures and help create a new era of mental wellness.</a></p>

<img alt="Equinox gym" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC81MTU4L2VxdWlub3hfZ3ltLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Alexi Rosenfeld/Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Stat: </strong>Luxury gym operator Equinox said new membership sales in NYC <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2021/05/19/equinox-says-cdcs-new-mask-guidance-sparked-surge-in-member-sign-ups.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">increased 55%</a> the week following the CDC's relaxation of mask requirements. Equinox no longer requires its members to wear masks while exercising, but still insists on mirror selfies post-workout. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Quote: </strong>"Technological advances also offer new possibilities to central banks—including the Fed."</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Fed Chair Jerome Powell said that his organization <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2021/05/20/the-fed-this-summer-will-take-another-step-ahead-in-developing-a-digital-currency.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">will explore issuing</a> a central bank digital currency (CBDC), which rivals including China are actively developing. The Fed will release a report this summer on the viability of CBDCs.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Read: </strong>A thought-provoking letter from the founder of ByteDance about why he's stepping down as CEO. (<a href="https://bytedance.com/en/news/60a526af053cc102d640c061?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">ByteDance</a>)</p>

<td style="padding-top: 12px;">

<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
BLACK WALL STREET
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="#" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Black Founders Need More Black Investors
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>

<a href="https://www.businesscasual.fm/black-founders-need-more-black-investors/" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Business Casual sponsorship " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC81MTUzL2J1c2luZXNzX2Nhc3VhbF9zcG9uc29yc2hpcC5qcGciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em></em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Morning Brew’s series commemorating the 100th anniversary of the Tulsa Race Massacre rolls on with even more fresh perspectives on the current state of Black finance.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">On our podcast, <em>Business Casual</em>, Jarrid Tingle told us about his VC firm's efforts to help close the funding gap to female and minority founders. <a href="https://www.businesscasual.fm/black-founders-need-more-black-investors/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Listen here</a>.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Then, read this <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/05/21/finance-people-color-shut-ever-get?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">first-person essay</a> from Sandrine Maurice, a public finance banker in SF who describes her experience working as a Black woman in the finance industry.</p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</th>
</tr>
</table>

Some loose oats are scattered around its base, and a few oat stalks are sticking out of the hole at the top like it's a vase. \" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC81MTU2L29hdGx5LmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19\"\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eFrancis Scialabba\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe humble oat has gotten a glow up from its days starring in grandma's porridge. Yesterday, shares in Oatly, the world's biggest oat milk maker, \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/europe-lifestyle-health-business-f5bf285bf70e1bf73d050656d110aa7e?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esoared\u003c/a\u003e 19% in its IPO, valuing the company at a trenta-sized $12 billion. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003e$12 billion for...oat milk?\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIf CEO Toni Petersson \u003ca href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_HQU0MB0D5A\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esinging\u003c/a\u003e, \"wow, no cow\" at the Super Bowl was your Oatly introduction...we regret to inform you that you were behind on this one.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eOatly's story \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2021/05/20/oatly-ipo-how-the-swedish-oat-milk-became-popular-in-us.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003estarts\u003c/a\u003e in 1994, when Swedish brothers Rickard and Bjorn Oeste began developing a milk alternative for the estimated two-thirds of people with lactose intolerance. But the company didn't become a household name until Petersson took over as CEO in 2014, refreshing Oatly's visual identity and reframing its marketing around oat milk's health and environmental benefits. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003ePetersson focused on the US market and built buzz by infiltrating corporate watering holes, i.e. NYC coffee shops. Oatly sent its product to specialty baristas, who introduced consumers to the new milk in a perfectly frothed form you'd never be able to replicate at home. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eSince then, Oatly's been keeping some A-list company. It \u003ca href=\"https://www.reuters.com/article/us-oatly-funding-idUSKCN24F1MG?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eraised\u003c/a\u003e money last year at a $2 billion valuation from names including Blackstone, Oprah, Natalie Portman, and Howard Schultz (whose former company, Starbucks, recently began using Oatly nationwide). Oatly's expanded to new products, including yogurt and ice cream, and now sells in 60k stores and 32k coffee shops worldwide.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eThe alternative milk market is steaming up\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAnd plenty of brands are scrambling for a spot on the menu. In the oat department alone, Oatly's got competition from Califia Farms, Chobani, Planet Oat, Pacific, and Danone's legacy alternative milk brands, Alpro and Silk.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBut oat milk is still second fiddle to almond milk. And a gander through your local grocery store’s dairy aisle will show you that companies are juicing every nut, grain, seed, and bean that can (even loosely) mimic the \"real\" thing.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line:\u003c/strong\u003e Oatly and other alternative milk brands seized on consumer demand for more environmentally friendly and healthy products. Their bet is paying off. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eRobinhood wants to clear up any hard feelings left over from January and yesterday \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2021/05/20/robinhood-will-give-retail-investors-access-to-ipo-shares-a-longstanding-wall-street-dominion.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eannounced\u003c/a\u003e that it’s rolling out a feature that allows users to access exclusive “IPO shares.” It touts this new service as another step in its mission to increase regular folks’ access to the stock market. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eHow IPO shares work: \u003c/strong\u003eBig Wall Street banks and high-net-worth individuals are often able to buy shares of a company that’s going public \u003cem\u003ebefore \u003c/em\u003ethey hit an exchange like Robinhood. And once those stocks do hit an exchange, regular investors can miss out on early gains. Companies popped an average of 36% on their first day of trading in 2020, per Dealogic.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe guinea pig: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eFigs, a maker of medical scrubs, became the \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.reuters.com/technology/robinhood-allow-users-buy-into-ipos-2021-05-20/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003efirst company\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e to offer IPO shares on Robinhood when it went public yesterday, reserving 1% of its 22.5 million shares for Robinhood users.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out:\u003c/strong\u003e SoFi, the fintech company that keeps asking if it can refinance your student loans, announced it would offer IPO shares in March. The main difference between SoFi’s and Robinhood’s offerings is that SoFi will be underwriting IPOs, while Robinhood is simply partnering with investment banks.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS
